recommendations.recommendation:
3.10....... You guys have become too cynical.. This anime was adorable and really well done especially for 2 brand new studios!
It has a ton of references but it generally doesn`t distract from the story which holds up on it`s own merit. Sure it`s "just another SoL series" but there is so many things they did well.. It`s hard to quantify, just watch it!
If nothing else keep an eye out for these studios, they will likely have some heavy hitters in the next few years.
(also not to be soap-boxy but some of you should take the time to remember why we fell in love with anime and what it means to us. A lot of fans, especially on this site, have become too critical and just jaded.. Yeah, everything is just a copy of a copy now.. But didn`t we learn anything from Kino no Tabi? The journey is the most important part not the end!)

anime.description: http://anidb.net/ch88900 [Asagaya Minoa] is a new high school student in Sakaneko Private High School. Despite being a novice to anime, Minoa`s classmate http://anidb.net/ch88899 [Kamiigusa Arisu] invites her to make an "anime research club" at school. Through conversations with her classmate http://anidb.net/ch88901 [Kouenji Miko], as well as various anime-loving upperclassmen, Minoa gradually gets hooked on anime. While they stand against the student council`s continuous efforts to disband their club, and they ignore the impending end of the world, they talk about anime, whether in Akiba, or in real-life "sacred place" anime settings, or the hot springs. Source: ANN

tag.name: dynamic
tag.description: Some of the central structural elements in anime are: Plot Continuity How does the plot or several plots unfold. Are they a strictly linear retelling of one big continuing story, a serial, possibly with several side stories, or is the content chopped into a set of unconnected episodes, only sharing the same setting and characters? Stereotype Characters Then there is the question of the character set presentation. Is it completely original, or is it your usual stereotypical character cast. Both choices have their merit, for example it would not really make much sense to reinvent the wheel for a harem anime. Fans of that genre come to expect their favourite stereotype protagonists. Plot Twists Finally there is the question of how complex the plot / the story unfolds. Are there side-plots that merge into the main plot leading to unexpected plot twists, or is the anime quite predictable? The latter would not be appropriate for detective stories. In harem anime on the other hand a foreseeable outcome is actually something the fans will come to expect.

tag.name: themes
tag.description: Themes describe the very central elements important to the anime stories. They set the backdrop against which the protagonists must face their challenges. Be it School Life, present Daily Life, Military action, Cyberpunk, Law and Order detective work, Sports, or the Underworld. These are only but a few of the more typical backgrounds for anime plots. Add to that a Conspiracy setting with a possible tragic outcome, the Themes span most of the imaginable subject matter relevant to anime.

tag.name: original work
tag.description: What the anime is based on! This is given as the original work credit in the OP. Mostly of academic interest, but a useful bit of info, hinting at the possible depth of story.

tag.name: elements
tag.description: Next to Themes setting the backdrop for the protagonists in anime, there are the more detailed plot Elements that centre on character interactions: "What do characters do to each other or what is done to them?". Is it violent Action, an awe-inspiring Adventure in a foreign place, the gripping life of a Detective, a slapstick Comedy, an Ecchi Harem anime, a SciFi epic, or some Fantasy travelling adventure?

tag.name: mecha
tag.description: Mecha in Japanese basically means mechanical things; everything from an electric whisk or a car to a spaceship or a robot. Here however we limit it to the more exotic things usually referred to as mecha anime: robots, whether controlled by a human or not, and their ilk. See Androids, Piloted Robots, Power Suits, Robot Helpers, Transforming Robots for a more specific classification.

tag.name: medium awareness
tag.description: Medium awareness is the situational and generally temporary awareness characters in works of fiction have and display of the very fact that they are characters in works of fiction. For example, they may comment about the background music, quip about the script or narration, complain about the roles given to them by the writer or their lack of screen time, see the subtitles that appear on screen, inform the audience about the arrival of the commercial break, and even use medium effects as tools. The most common form of medium awareness is known as breaking the fourth wall, in which characters speak directly to the audience, either to it as a whole or to specific members of it. The "fourth wall" is the imaginary "wall" at the front of the stage of a proscenium theatre through which the audience sees the play; it is a metaphor for the boundary between what happens inside the work, to the characters, and outside it, to the audience.

tag.name: parody
tag.description: Anime that imitate other stories (can be from TV, film, books, historical events, ...) for comic effect by exaggerating the style and changing the content of the original. Also known as spoofs. It can also refer to when whole elements of one work are lifted out of their context and reused.

tag.name: school clubs
tag.description: Even though school clubs in Japan are not mandatory, there is some pressure from the social grid (e.g. fellow students, teachers) to participate in some kind of after-school activity, be it in sports or arts. Colleges also have clubs. As a comedy element in anime, some students have joined too many clubs, and are thus constantly stressed out. There is also the element of social commentary, making it clear that you have to join a club, if you want to be part of the class. Since self-founded clubs need at least 3 members, the desperate search and advertising for new members can be cause for hilarity in anime.

tag.name: new
tag.description: Not based on anything, the story is a new work, usually made up by the people involved in creating the anime. Generally if an original work (原作) credit is given, it will be to the studio, or director, or other members of the production team.

tag.name: science fiction
tag.description: Science fiction stories usually focus on how situations could be different in the future when we are more technologically advanced; due to either our own achievements or having met with other civilizations whom we have learned from.

tag.name: comedy
tag.description: Anime whose central struggle causes hilarious results. These stories are built upon funny characters, situations and events. A comedy anime is laced with humour and sets out to provoke laughter from the audience. Japanese humour can be a bit strange to westerners, so if you`re new to this type of humour, just bear with it; it`ll most likely grow on you if you`re a fan of other kinds of comedy.

tag.name: school life
tag.description: Since a large part of the anime audience still takes part in school life or is visiting college, it is only natural to choose a setting the audience can identify with, be it elementary, middle, or high school. For the older viewers a college setting with more mature real-life problems is appropriate. And since clubs take up so much time in the lives of students, these are obviously also important.

tag.name: OP and ED sung by characters
tag.description: OP and/or ED in this anime is sung by the characters and animation shows them singing.

tag.name: self-parody
tag.description: The anime is a parody of itself. I.e. the authors make fun of the genre they are portraying, and take the actions of their characters and story lightly.

tag.name: female protagonist
tag.description: The anime has a female protagonist.

tag.name: otaku culture
tag.description: Otaku (おたく/オタク) is a Japanese term used to refer to people with obsessive interests, particularly anime, manga, and video games. A female otaku is occasionally referred to as a fujoshi. (Source: Wikipedia) Here certain aspects of this "fandom" are presented in more detail, e.g. the creation of doujinshi (self-published amateur manga).

tag.name: technical aspects
tag.description: It may sometimes be useful to know about technical aspects of a show, such as information about its broadcasting or censorship. Such information can be found here.

tag.name: speculative fiction
tag.description: Speculative fiction is an umbrella genre encompassing fiction with certain elements that do not exist in the real world, often in the context of supernatural, futuristic or other imaginative themes. This includes, but is not limited to, science fiction, fantasy, superhero fiction, horror, utopian and dystopian fiction, fairytale fantasy, supernatural fiction, as well as combinations thereof. Source: Wikipedia

episode.title: アニメガタリズ放送直前! 中国上陸! 豪華おもてなしと思いきや大事件SP!!
Episode S1
Anime-Gataris Housou Chokuzen! Chuukoku Jouriku! Gouka Omotenashi to Omoikiya Daijiken SP!!
ブシツ, ダイバクハツ!
Club Room Go Boom!
Explosion dans la salle du club !
동아리실, 대폭파!
Bushitsu, Daibakuhatsu!
episode.summary: Arisu orders a mountain of anime from Numazon, leading to a student council investigation on the club’s spending. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: エリカ, レイヤーxレイヤー
Erika, Cosplayer x Cosplayer
Erika, Layer x Layer
에리카, 레이어 x 레이어
Erika, Layer x Layer
episode.summary: The student council is threatening to abolish the Anime Club. The gang heads to Akihabara to clear their minds as they try to come up with a way to save the club. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ツドエ, アニメガタリズ
Anime-Gataris, Assemble!
Anime-gataris, le rassemblement !
츠도에, 애니메 가타리즈
Tsudoe, Anime-Gataris
episode.summary: The new Anime Club is in search of new members. The odds are good, but the goods are a little bit odd -- perhaps in a good way. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ミノア, アニメルーキー!
Minoa, Anime Rookie!
Minoa, anime rookie!
미노아, 애니메 루키
Minoa, Anime Rookie!
episode.summary: First-year high school student Asagaya Minoa is not much of an anime nerd, but there is a show that she watched as a child, but can`t remember the name of. Kamiigusa Arisu, the well-to-do resident anime otaku of her class, might be able to help. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: アリス, オカネガタリマセンワ
Arisu Can`t Make Enough Money
Alice, insérez une pièce de monnaie
아리스, 돈이 부족합니다
Arisu, Okane ga Tarimasen wa
episode.summary: The club struggles to finish their anime on time and has to deal with problem how to fill all the seats with people during the screening. But Minoa has an idea that could help them.

episode.title: ミコ, ダンピツセンゲン
Miko Quits Writing
Miko jette l`éponge
미코, 절필선언
Miko, Danpitsu Sengen
episode.summary: The school council threatens to disband the club again. Then Minoa comes with the idea that the club should create their very own anime.

episode.title: カイカイ, ラブクライマックス
Kaikai Love Climax
Kai-kai, Love Climax
카이카이, 러브 클라이맥스
Kaikai, Love Climax
episode.summary: The club heads out on their summer trip, checking out all the anime meccas. Something seems to be going on between Kaikai and Miko, but she’s not making herself very clear. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ベイベー, イケナイススメナイ
Beibei, Don`t Go
Bay bey, j`en peux plus !
베이비, 앞으로 갈 수 없어
Beibei, Ikenai Susumenai
episode.summary: The club heads to “the” summer anime event, where they get lost, melt, and meet interesting people. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ミノア, カタルシス
Minoa, Katharsis
Minoa, catharsis !
미노아, 카타르시스
Minoa, Catharsis
episode.summary: Minoa is desperately looking for a way to restore the world, but with the season ending, time is running out. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 共ニ語リシ光輝[めいゆう]ノ裏切リ
Our Friend Kouki`s Second Betrayal
Parlons ensemble de la trahison d`un grand ami
함께 얘기 나누던 동료 나카노의 배신
Tomo ni Katarishi Meiyuu no Uragiri
episode.summary: The world is beginning to make less and less sense, and only Minoa seems to notice. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: アニケン, ヤットハイブ
Anime Club Finally Falls
La vrai fin du club de japanimation
애니 연구부, 드디어 폐부
Aniken, Yatto Haibu
episode.summary: Minoa approaches the principal to try to get him to bring back the Anime Club. She is locked inside the office with him, and the others scramble to help her get out. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: アニケン, ズットテング
The Anime Club: Forever Snobs
Le club de japanimation fanfaronne
애니 연구부, 붕 뜬 마음
Aniken, Zutto Tengu
episode.summary: The Anime Club discovers that they can solve people’s problems by recommending inspirational anime fit for their clubs. This works out great – a little too great. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: グッドラックライラック FullCGver
Good Luck Lilac Full CG Version
